The "Renewable Energy, Fuel Reduction, and Economic Stabilization and Enhancement Act of 2007" or the "REFRESH Act" promotes geothermal power development through grants to eligible entities and authorizes $100,000,000 for this purpose. Additionally, the Act includes provisions for ocean energy development. The "REFRESH Act" promotes geothermal power development through grants to eligible entities and authorizes $100,000,000 for this purpose. It also includes provisions for ocean energy development and plug-in hybrid electric-combustion engine vehicles. The "REFRESH Act" amends testing and calculation procedures for measuring fuel economy in passenger automobiles, using procedures described in a final rule from 2006. The amendment will take effect 5 years after the enactment of the Act and apply to automobiles manufactured after that date. The "REFRESH Act" amends fuel economy standards for passenger automobiles manufactured after a certain date. The Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration will conduct a study on the economic impacts and fuel saving benefits of requiring vehicles with a gross weight of 10,000 pounds to meet specific fuel economy standards. A report with study results and recommendations will be submitted to Congress within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The "REFRESH Act" amends fuel economy standards for passenger automobiles manufactured after a certain date. Vehicles with a gross weight of 10,000 pounds should meet specific fuel economy standards. The "REFRESH Act" updates fuel economy standards for passenger automobiles. It also introduces tire resistance standards and traffic reduction grants to incentivize telecommuting and flexible work scheduling. $50,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2008 for the grant program. TITLE III--TAX CREDITS

SEC. 301. EXPANSION OF CREDIT FOR PRODUCTION OF ENERGY FROM CERTAIN RENEWABLE RESOURCES. Expansion of Resources to Wave, Current, Tidal, and Ocean Thermal Energy, amending the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to include these energy sources for electricity production. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes wave, current, tidal, and ocean thermal energy as qualified facilities for electricity production. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 expands the definition of small irrigation power to include power generated without dams or impoundments, with a capacity rating of less than 15 megawatts. The amendments made by this section apply to electricity produced in taxable years ending after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 302 extends and modifies the new qualified hybrid motor vehicle credit for plug-in hybrids. Extension of tax credits for new qualified hybrid motor vehicles and light trucks until December 31, 2012, with specific provisions for vehicles recharged by off board devices. Elimination of limitations on the number of eligible vehicles for full alternative motor vehicle tax credit. The Motor Vehicle Tax Credit under Section 30B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by removing subsection (f) and redesignating subsections (g) through (j) as subsections (f) through (i). Conforming amendments are made to related sections of the Code. The Motor Vehicle Tax Credit under Section 30B of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by changing subsection references from (g) to (f) in various sections. These amendments apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2005.
